column2: WI) purchased numerous original [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]] manuscripts in [[1957]] for 1
column4: 000). The Marquette University Libraries now hold most likely the world's largest collection of items relating to J.R.R. Tolkien (including more than 11
column5: 000 original manuscripts and multiple working drafts of ''The Lord of the Rings'' and ''The Hobbit''
column8: and other material by and about Tolkien). [[Matt Blessing]] is currently in charge of maintaining the collection.

column1: In late December [[1956]] or early January [[1957]] [[William Ready]]
column2: the Director of Libraries at Marquette University
column3: was compiling the University's research-related collections and he asked Bertram Rota
column4: a well-known London bookseller if she could approach J.R.R. Tolkien to see if he was willing to sell the original manuscripts of ''[[The Hobbit]]'' and ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''. Rota wrote to Tolkien and prior to [[10 January|January 10]]th Tolkien replied.

column2: Bertram Rota responded to William Ready at Marquette. Tolkien was willing to consider selling his manuscripts but asked what amount the University was willing to offer. He sent a list of ''The Hobbit'' and ''The Lord of the Rings'' material he considered selling. Rota suggested to Ready a minimum offer of £1
column4: however she would have liked to examine the documents personally before the final decision was made.

column1: Tolkien wished to visit the University but was held back every time
